content: The Internet Tax Freedom Act Amendments Act of 2007, also known as the Internet Tax Freedom Act, extends the moratorium on internet taxes until 2014 and includes provisions for grandfathering states that tax internet access. The Internet Tax Freedom Act Amendments Act of 2007 extends the moratorium on internet taxes until 2014 and includes provisions for grandfathering states that tax internet access. Section 1104 of the Act defines 'Internet access' for subsections (a) and (b) until June 30, 2008. The Internet Tax Nondiscrimination Act, under Public Law 108-435, has exceptions for taxes on Internet access until June 30, 2008. These exceptions apply to taxes on telecommunications services purchased, used, or sold by Internet access providers if certain conditions are met. The Internet Tax Nondiscrimination Act has exceptions for taxes on Internet access until June 30, 2008. These exceptions apply to taxes on telecommunications services purchased, used, or sold by Internet access providers if certain conditions are met, including litigation in a judicial court. No inference of legislative construction shall be drawn from this subsection. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. Section 1105 of the Internet Tax Freedom Act is amended to clarify the definition of Internet access services, including the purchase, use, or sale of telecommunications to enable users to connect to the Internet. The definition of Internet access services under the Internet Tax Freedom Act includes services that enable users to access content, information, or other services over the Internet. It also covers incidental services provided as part of the main service, but excludes voice, audio, or video programming that utilize Internet protocol and have a separate charge. The Internet Tax Freedom Act defines Internet access services as services that allow users to access content, information, or other services over the Internet. It includes incidental services but excludes voice, audio, or video programming with a separate charge. The Internet Tax Freedom Act defines telecommunications and telecommunications services according to the Communications Act of 1934 and the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It also specifies a specific exception for taxes on Internet access starting from November 1, 2007. The Internet Tax Freedom Act exempts State taxes on commercial activity, modified gross receipts, taxable margin, or gross income from being considered as a tax on Internet access, effective November 1, 2007. The Internet Tax Freedom Act exempts certain taxes enacted between June 20, 2005, and November 1, 2007, or between January 1, 1932, and January 1, 1936, that replaced value-added or net income taxes, are imposed broadly on business activity, and are not discriminatory towards communication services or Internet access providers. The Internet Tax Freedom Act allows states to modify taxes covered by the Act as long as the changes do not significantly limit the scope of the tax. No implications should be drawn from these modifications regarding the application of the Act to taxes before November 1, 2007. SEC. 5 of the Internet Tax Freedom Act is amended to include telecommunications and enable users to access content over the Internet. Section 1108 is removed by SEC. 6, which addresses the sunset of grandfather provisions. SEC. 6 of the Internet Tax Freedom Act addresses the sunset of grandfather provisions, stating that certain states are exempt from taxes on Internet access if they have repealed such taxes more than 24 months prior to the enactment of this provision. SEC. 7 specifies that the Act and its amendments will take effect on November 1, 2007, applying to existing and future taxes, with exceptions outlined in section 1104 of the Act. The Act and its amendments will be effective from November 1, 2007, applying to existing and future taxes, with exceptions outlined in section 1104 of the Internet Tax Freedom Act.
